text:
"Please sit down," he said suddenly. "I want to talk to you. You might be in a hurry, but please give me two minutes," and he pulled a chair for her.

Sonia sat down again and nervously glanced at the two ladies, then looked down. Raskolnikov's pale face turned red, and he felt a shiver. His eyes lit up.

"Mother," he said firmly, "this is Sofya Semyonovna Marmeladov, the daughter of that poor Mr. Marmeladov, who was run over yesterday while I was watching, and I was just telling you about him."

Pulcheria Alexandrovna looked at Sonia and squinted a bit. Even though she felt awkward under Rodya's intense gaze, she couldn’t help but feel a bit pleased. Dounia looked seriously at Sonia’s face, trying to understand her. Sonia, hearing her name, tried to look up again but felt even more shy.

"I wanted to ask you," Raskolnikov said quickly, "how everything was handled yesterday. Were you worried about the police, for example?"

"No, that was fine... it was obvious how he died... they didn’t bother us... just the lodgers are upset."

"Why?"

"Because the body has been there too long. It’s hot now. So today, they will take it to the cemetery, into the chapel, until tomorrow. At first, Katerina Ivanovna was..."

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Raskolnikov introduces Sonia, the daughter of the deceased Marmeladov, to his mother and sister while expressing concern about the funeral arrangements.
